case_name: Bhagat Ram v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 36 of 1969 and 202 of 1970 filed before Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 17, 1969 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Criminal Appeal No. 376 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 17, 1969 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Criminal Appeal No. 376 of 1965. S. R. Chari and Sobhagmal Jain, for the appellant

facts.text: Bhagat Ram posted as circle inspector of police at Ganganagar during 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagat Ram during the year 1962 was posted as circle ins- pector of police at Ganganagar. Ancestral village of Bhagat Ram is Mehna in Tehsil Moga, District Ferozepur.

facts.text: Ancestral village of Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop is Mehna in Tehsil Moga, District Ferozepur.

facts.text: Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop tried by special judge, Ganganagar for offences under section 120B IPC for conspiring to extort bribe of Rs. 2,000 from PW 1 Niranjan Dass.

anchor.surface_text: Both Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop were tried in the companyrt of special judge, Ganga- nagar for offenses under section 120B IPC for companyspiring to ,extort bribe of Rs. 2,000 from P W I Niranjan Dass of Moga.

facts.text: Special judge, Ganganagar acquitted Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop of all charges.

anchor.surface_text: Both Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop were acquitted by the special judge, Ganganagar in respect of all the charges. The State of Rajasthan filed an appeal against the acquittal

facts.text: State of Rajasthan filed appeal against acquittal of Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop.

issues.text: Whether the third judge under section 429 CrPC could reopen and set aside the acquittal of Bhagat Ram for offences under sections 120B, 218, 347 and 389 IPC when the Division Bench had unanimously dismissed the State appeal on those charges?

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the State appeal against the acquittal of Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218, 347 and 389 I P C had been dismissed by the Division Bench, it was, in our opinion, not permissible for the third judge to reopen the matter and convict Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218 and 347 IPC despite the order of the Division Bench.

issues.text: Whether the principle of res judicata and autrefois acquit applies to bind the third judge to the Division Bench's order upholding acquittal on certain charges?

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Division Bench unless set aside in appeal to this Court, was binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties. The principle of res judicata is also applicable to criminal proceedings and it is not permissible in the subsequent stage of the same proceedings or in some other subsequent proceedings to convict a person for an offence in respect of which an order for his acquittal has already been recorded.

issues.text: Whether the charge of criminal conspiracy under section 120B IPC against Bhagat Ram can be sustained after the acquittal of co-conspirator Ram Swaroop?

anchor.surface_text: The charge under section 120B IPC related to conspiracy between Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop for extorting Rs. 2,000 as illegal gratification from Niranjan Dass. When Ram Swaroop was acquitted of the charge under section 120B IPC, the basis of the charge against Bhagat Ram for conspiracy between him and Ram Swaroop disappeared.

issues.text: Whether Bhagat Ram's acquittal under sections 120B, 218, 347 IPC by the trial court and Division Bench should be interfered with?

anchor.surface_text: In view of the difference between the two judges regarding the acquittal of Bhagat Ram for offenses under section 161 IPC and 5 1 a of Prevention of Corruption Act, the case was placed under section 429 of the Code of Criminal Procedure before Jagat Narayan, J.

issues.text: Whether Bhagat Ram can be convicted under section 161 IPC and section 5(1)(a) of Prevention of Corruption Act absent direct demand for gratification and given acquittal of alleged intermediary Ram Swaroop?

anchor.surface_text: As regards the conviction of Bhagat Ram for the offence under section 161 IPC, we find that it is not the prosecution case that Bhagat Ram had made any demand directly to Niranjan Dass for payment of illegal gratification. ... The case set up by the prosecution is that Bhagat Ram attempted to obtain illegal gratification from Niranjan Dass through the instrumentality of Ram Swaroop.

issues.text: Whether the State appeal against acquittal of Ram Swaroop under sections 120B and 165A IPC deserves interference given concurrent findings?

anchor.surface_text: So far as the State appeal against the acquittal of Ram Swaroop is concerned, we find that there are concurrent findings of the trial court and the High Court that the evidence on record had failed to prove that he was guilty of offenses under sections 120B and 165A IPC.

holdings.text: The third judge under section 429 CrPC cannot reopen and convict on charges where the Division Bench unanimously dismissed the State appeal upholding acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the State appeal against the acquittal of Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218, 347 and 389 I P C had been dismissed by the Division Bench, it was, in our opinion, not permissible for the third judge to reopen the matter and convict Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218 and 347 IPC despite the order of the Division Bench.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference under s.429 limited to point of difference; Division Bench acquittal on other charges binding and cannot be reopened by third judge.

holdings.text: The principle of res judicata and autrefois acquit applies to criminal proceedings, making Division Bench acquittal binding on third judge unless set aside on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Division Bench unless set aside in appeal to this Court, was binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties. The principle of res judicata is also applicable to criminal proceedings and it is number permissible in the subsequent stage of the same proceedings or in some other subsequent proceedings to convict a person for an offence in respect of which an order for his acquittal has already been recorded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench order conclusive; res judicata and s.403 CrPC bar reopening acquittal; cites Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor and Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab.

holdings.text: Conviction under section 120B IPC against Bhagat Ram cannot stand after acquittal of co-conspirator Ram Swaroop, as charge specifically alleged conspiracy between them.

anchor.surface_text: The, charge under section 120B IPC related to , companyspiracy between Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop for extorting Rs. 2,000 as illegal gratification from Niranjan Dass. When Ram Swaroop was acquitted of the charge under section 120B IPC, the basis of the charge against Bhagat Ram for companyspiracy between him and Ram, Swaroop disappeared.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conspiracy requires agreement between specific persons named; acquittal of named co-conspirator eliminates basis of charge.

holdings.text: No interference with concurrent acquittal of Bhagat Ram under sections 120B, 218, 347 IPC by trial court and Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the State appeal against the acquittal of Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218, 347 and 389 I P C had been dismissed by the Division Bench, it was, in our opinion, not permissible for the third judge to reopen the matter and convict Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218 and 347 IPC despite the order of the Division Bench.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench unanimously upheld trial acquittal; binding under res judicata; third judge erred in interfering.

holdings.text: Conviction of Bhagat Ram under section 161 IPC and s.5(1)(a) Prevention of Corruption Act cannot be sustained absent direct demand and given acquittal of intermediary Ram Swaroop.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the companyviction of Bhagat Ram for the offence under section 161 IPC, we find that it is number the prosecution case that Bhagat Ram had made any demand directly to Niranjan Dass for payment of illegal gratification. ... The case set up by the prosecution is that Bhagat Ram attempted to obtain illegal gratification from Niranjan Dass through the instrumentality of Ram Swaroop.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prosecution case of direct demand; entire case rested on unproved agency of acquitted Ram Swaroop; inconsistent to convict principal while acquitting agent.

holdings.text: State appeal against acquittal of Ram Swaroop under sections 120B and 165A IPC not to be interfered with due to concurrent findings of trial court and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the State appeal against the acquittal of Rain Swaroop is companycerned, we find that there are companycurrent findings of the trial companyrt and the High Court that the evidence on record had failed to prove that he was guilty of offenses under sections 120B and 165A IPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings that evidence insufficient; no basis to reappraise evidence.

precedents.citation: Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor, Federal of Malaya 1

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor, Federal of Malaya 1 , Lord MacDermott observed The effect of a verdict of acquittal pronounced by a competent Court on a lawful charge and after a lawful trial is not completely stated by saying that the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence.

precedents.case_name: Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor, Federal of Malaya
precedents.cited_proposition: Effect of a verdict of acquittal is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties; maxim res judicata applies to criminal proceedings
precedents.cited_holding: The effect of a verdict of acquittal pronounced by a competent Court on a lawful charge and after a lawful trial is not completely stated by saying that the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence. To that it must be added that the verdict is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties to the adjudication.

precedents.citation: Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab 2

anchor.surface_text: The above observations were quoted with approval by this Court in the case of Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab 2 . We are, therefore, of the opinion that the judgment of Jagat Narayan, J. in so far as he has convicted Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218 and 347 IPC cannot be sustained.

precedents.case_name: Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Quoted with approval the observations from Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor on binding nature of acquittal verdict

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, accept the appeal of Bhagat Ram and set aside .his companyviction and acquit him. The appeal of the State of Rajasthan against the acquittal of Ram Swaroop is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Bhagat Ram's appeal allowed; conviction and sentence set aside; Bhagat Ram acquitted. State of Rajasthan's appeal against Ram Swaroop's acquittal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the State appeal against the acquittal of Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218, 347 and 389 I P C had been dismissed by the Division Bench, it was, in our opinion, not permissible for the third judge to reopen the matter and convict Bhagat Ram for offenses under sections 120B, 218 and 347 IPC despite the order of the Division Bench.
We, therefore, accept the appeal of Bhagat Ram and set aside .his companyviction and acquit him. The appeal of the State of Rajasthan against the acquittal of Ram Swaroop is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Division Bench unless set aside in appeal to this Court, was binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties. The principle of res judicata is also applicable to criminal proceedings and it is number permissible in the subsequent stage of the same proceedings or in some other subsequent proceedings to convict a person for an offence in respect of which an order for his acquittal has already been recorded.
We, therefore, accept the appeal of Bhagat Ram and set aside .his companyviction and acquit him. The appeal of the State of Rajasthan against the acquittal of Ram Swaroop is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The, charge under section 120B IPC related to , companyspiracy between Bhagat Ram and Ram Swaroop for extorting Rs. 2,000 as illegal gratification from Niranjan Dass. When Ram Swaroop was acquitted of the charge under section 120B IPC, the basis of the charge against Bhagat Ram for companyspiracy between him and Ram, Swaroop disappeared.
We, therefore, accept the appeal of Bhagat Ram and set aside .his companyviction and acquit him. The appeal of the State of Rajasthan against the acquittal of Ram Swaroop is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the companyviction of Bhagat Ram for the offence under section 161 IPC, we find that it is number the prosecution case that Bhagat Ram had made any demand directly to Niranjan Dass for payment of illegal gratification. ... The case set up by the prosecution is that Bhagat Ram attempted to obtain illegal gratification from Niranjan Dass through the instrumentality of Ram Swaroop.
We, therefore, accept the appeal of Bhagat Ram and set aside .his companyviction and acquit him. The appeal of the State of Rajasthan against the acquittal of Ram Swaroop is dismissed.
